Review: THIS GAME SAVED MY LIFE I am 42. My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old. When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide. After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side. Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay. After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as. Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends. I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together. Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that. Thank you.

Review: A tough and difficult review for this entry. I will do my utmost to make it concise yet informative. 1) Features: Graphic still looks awesome for current trend, music even though no longer composed by Nobuo Uematsu, it still holds up on its own accord though some of them are not really on my preferences, but some really do like the Gran Pulse main theme. Additionally, SEA region version only receives Japanese audio as compared with ROW versions. This is a big letdown to me, as I like to keep on switching language in different palythrough. 2) Gameplay: Battle system somehow quite similar with Chrono Chross yet active input is required without pause setting for ATB gauge to filled up. Might took some time to familiarised with this new system for established FF fans, yet it is an interesting system once you get to used it. Different strategic tactics can be applied, though I'm not really keen with this system. Customisation of equipments and accessories, and levelling up via crystarium are nicely implemented and deter players to keep on mindless grinding. However battle rating could be implemented better, not focusing too much on time and damage applied, and not really into the "doom" imposed if you are to be involved in a battle for a longer time. 3) Story: be prepared to keep on hearing these famous words; fal'Cie, l'Cie. Caccoon, Pulse, Focus, etc. Storyline is filled with interesting mythology but quite poorly implemented on my humble opinion. Direction is quite linear, but hang in there as reaching to chapter 11 will improve your experience better (for FF veterans). 4) Replay value: Quite high, considering many equipments require expensive catalysts and many gill (game currency) required. Second playthrough might change the experience drastically. 5) Optimisation: Slight poorly optimised, several drop in FPS experienced in several area such as in Gran Pulse, glitch in datalog text (enemy descriptions) apart from 1280x720 resolution. Audio is too low and unadjustable. Limited customisation on keyboard binding capabilities. Esc and Steam home keys sometimes unresponsive. Apart from that, cutscene and graphic as stated earlier, are looking great. What I really like about this game: Graphic and FMVs, certain music, development of certain characters, certain implementation on the paradigm, mythology of the game What I really dislike of this game: Quite linear storyline with less to nill interaction with npcs, most informations could be given indirectly instead of relying in conversation and datalog methods (especially mythology of the game), paradigm shifting/transitions could be better. Finally, I really dislike this game in SEA region is only restricted in Japanese audio as compared with ROW version. Neutral: Difficulty spike, action in combat, system concerning upgrading accessories and weapons. Final remarks: I would like to give this a neutral since halfway of the game, since I forced myself playing this game on numerous occasions until I reached out at chapter 11. Nevertheless, this game is good, but not that bad either. So its a yes from me. FF veterans might not favour this game, but I do encourage them to try and hold on until reaching to the Gran Pulse area. I would like to replay this game from scratch with different language, as in certain language, voice actors may perfoms differently compared with the original voice actors. This might yield different personification of certain characters. Tested on: Dell Inspiron SE 7520 Windows 10 64 bit Intel core i7 3621QM AMD Radeon HD 7520 2 GB VRAM 8 GB RAM 1 TB HDD
